title: Classic Home Stereos
description: From console stereos to component systems, how well do you remember home audio?

questions.question: What large piece of furniture combined a record player, radio, and speakers in one wooden cabinet during the 1950s and 1960s?
What did 'hi-fi' stand for when people talked about their home stereo systems?
Which brand was famous for its 'All-in-One' console stereos and became synonymous with quality home audio in the 1960s?
What type of audio tape format, housed in a large plastic cartridge, was popular for home stereo systems in the late 1960s and early 1970s?
Which turntable speed, measured in RPM, was standard for playing full-length LP albums?
What component of a turntable holds the needle that reads the grooves on a vinyl record?
Which Japanese brand became hugely popular in the 1970s for affordable, high-quality component stereo systems?
What was a common name for the large, floor-standing speakers that audiophiles favored in the 1970s?
The compact cassette tape, which became a staple of home stereos, was introduced by which company in 1963?
What feature on stereo receivers allowed listeners to pick up FM stereo broadcasts, which became widespread in the 1960s?
Which brand used the advertising tagline 'Is it live, or is it Memorex?' in commercials featuring Ella Fitzgerald?
What was the name for a stereo system where separate components like the receiver, turntable, and tape deck were stacked together?
Which audio format, introduced by Sony and Philips in 1982, eventually replaced vinyl records as the primary music medium?
What small adapter was needed to play 45 RPM singles on a turntable designed for LPs?
What was the popular term for making a personal compilation of songs recorded onto a blank cassette tape?
